title: 107_hr2097
content: The "Child Care Quality Incentive Act of 2001" may be cited as such. The "Child Care Quality Incentive Act of 2001" highlights findings on early brain development, emphasizing the importance of quality early care and education for children's cognitive abilities and long-term success. Research shows that many child care centers do not promote healthy development or ensure the safety of children. Full-day child care can be costly, ranging from $4,000 to $10,000 per child. Child care centers provide care that promotes healthy development, but 1 in 8 centers pose risks to children's safety. Full-day child care costs $4,000 to $10,000 per year. Federal assistance for child care is limited, making it unaffordable for many families. Payment rates for child care providers are too low to ensure quality care for all families. Low payment rates for child care providers impact the quality of care children receive, leading to staff cuts, lack of training, and reduced educational activities. This results in delayed development and increased aggression in children. Increasing payment rates can improve the quality of child care. Increasing payment rates for child care providers can lead to higher quality care, improved staff qualifications, safer environments, and better educational materials. This Act aims to enhance child care quality and accessibility by raising payment rates. Incentive grants are provided to improve the quality of child care. Funding for grants to improve the quality of child care is authorized with $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 and additional funds for subsequent years. Block grant funds can be used for this purpose. Funding for grants to improve the quality of child care is authorized with $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 and additional funds for subsequent years. Block grant funds can be used for this purpose, with specific amendments made to sections 658E(c)(3), 658G(a), and the addition of a new section 658H in the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. "Grants to improve the quality of child care are authorized with $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 and additional funds for subsequent years." The Secretary will use funds to make grants to eligible States for child care services based on market rates surveys conducted within 2 years. States must submit an application to receive annual payments. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a State must submit an application detailing the methodology and results of the market rates survey conducted within 2 years. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a State must detail the methodology and results of the market rates survey, describe the plan to increase payment rates, and explain how rates will be raised in line with survey results. The Secretary may only make annual payments to eligible States that show progress in assisted activities. To receive a grant under this section, a State must conduct a survey every two years and show progress in maintaining increased payment rates. The State must also provide matching funds of at least 25% of the costs for activities under subsection (d). State contributions must be in cash and not include Federal Government funds. Allotted funds for eligible States follow the same process as under section 658O(b). Grants received by eligible States should be used to increase payment rates significantly. An eligible State receiving a grant under this section must increase the payment rate for child care assistance up to the 100th percentile of the market rate survey. Once achieving this rate, the State can use the funds for activities enhancing the quality of child care services. The State must increase payment rates for child care assistance up to the 100th percentile of the market rate survey to receive a grant under this section. The funds should be used to supplement, not supplant, other federal, state, or local funds. States must submit evaluations to the Secretary on efforts to increase payment rates and their impact on child care quality and accessibility. The Secretary will report to Congress on these evaluations. The Secretary will submit biennial reports to Congress on efforts to increase payment rates for child care and their impact on quality and accessibility. The term 'payment rate' refers to reimbursement rates for subsidized child care providers. Section 658J(a) of the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to include funds appropriated under section 658B(a) for payments. Section 658O addresses the allotment of funds for child care development.
